    You are Player 1 and the other agent is Player 2.

    Both you and Player 2 have a private value per unit of each item type.
    These values are drawn from a uniform random distribution, ranging from 1 to 101.
    Your private values are 50 for item 1, 65 for item 2, 69 for item 3, 70 for item 4, 7 for item 5.
    You have a private outside offer drawn from a uniform random distribution ranging from 1 to your total value of all items, which is 1060. Player 2 has a private outside offer drawn from a uniform random distribution ranging from 1 to to their total value of all items.
    Your outside offer value is 783. 

    The negotiation proceeds in 3 rounds.
    There is a discount rate gamma = 0.98, such that if the process concludes after r rounds the overall value of the negotiation to each player is their value for the outcome multiplied by gamma to the power (r-1).
    At each round, Player 1 takes an action, followed by Player 2.
    The possible actions are to ACCEPT the other player's current offer (if any), make a COUNTEROFFER, or WALK away.  If the game gets to the last round, and player 2 chooses to make a counteroffer, this is treated as a WALK.
    If a player chooses ACCEPT, the negotiation ends in a deal to divide the items according to the accepted offer.
    The value of an outcome is determined by each player's private values per unit of each item and the quantities they receive in the deal. This value is adjusted by the discount factor, which is used to compute the present value of the negotiation outcome.
    If a player chooses WALK, the negotiation ends without a deal, and each player receives the value of their private outside offer.

    Please show your reasoning step by step, then provide your action in one of these formats in your response (if you do not do this your response will be invalid):
    {"action": "ACCEPT"} - to accept the current offer
    {"action": "WALK"} - to walk away from negotiations  
    {"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [n1, n2, ...]} - where n1, n2, ... are numbers representing the number of units of each item being offered to the other player as part of the counteroffer.

    Any response not in these exact formats will be invalid and treated as a WALK. If you provide a counteroffer, it must be a valid offer, otherwise it will be treated as a WALK.

    It is now round 1.

        What is your action? As the first player, your available actions are:

round_data.response:
I'll explain my reasoning briefly.

My total value if I received every unit would be 1060. To get a deal that I prefer to “walking away” (my outside offer of 783) I must secure an allocation worth at least 783. In effect, I have a “concession budget” of 1060 – 783 = 277 (that is, I can “give away” items whose total “worth” to me is at most 277). Knowing my own per‐unit values—
 • item 1: 50,
 • item 2: 65,
 • item 3: 69,
 • item 4: 70,
 • item 5: 7—
I want to concede primarily those items that cost me little while (likely) giving my opponent high “subjective” value. In particular, item 5 is very “cheap” for me (7 per unit) even though an opponent drawn from U[1,101] has expected per‐unit values of roughly 51. Similarly, among the remaining items item 1 costs me 50 per unit (lowest among items 1–4). By “buying” each unit in item 1 I lose 50 while an opponent might well appreciate about 51 per unit. (The other items cost more to me, so conceding any of them would push my own share too low.) 

One possible offer is to give the opponent 5 units of item 1 and all 2 units of item 5. Then my “cost” is 5·50 + 2·7 = 250 + 14 = 264, leaving my own share’s value as 1060 – 264 = 796, which is just above my reservation of 783. (My allocation in that case would be: item 1: 1 unit, item 2: all 4 units, item 3: all 4 units, item 4: all 3 units, item 5: 0 units.) 

From an opponent’s perspective, if we assume his “average” value per unit is roughly 51 then the offer gives him an “expected” value of 5·51 + 2·51 = 357. Although that may seem low compared to the average expected outside offer, my own reservation forces me to be tough in round 1 if I wish to beat 783. (In later rounds I might have to concede more; here I’m forced to “gamble” with a tough offer hoping that his actual private values—or his outside offer—are lower.)

Given all this, as Player 1 in round 1 I propose to offer Player 2 the following division: give Player 2 5 units of item 1, 0 units of item 2, 0 units of item 3, 0 units of item 4, and all 2 units of item 5.

Thus, my action is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [5, 0, 0, 0, 2]}

round_data.response:
I want to produce an initial offer that, from my own point‐of–view, splits the total available “pie” roughly evenly between us and my counteroffer is attractive enough (given discounting and our outside offers) that Player 2 might consider it rather than walking away. (Of course I do not know Player 2’s precise values, but symmetry is a natural starting point.) 

Let me explain my reasoning. My total value if I received every unit was 
  5×69 + 5×21 + 5×57 + 5×41 + 7×53 = 1311. 
My private outside offer is 487, so any deal I get immediately (round 1, so no discount) should give me at least more than 487. An equally split deal (by my own numbers) would give me roughly half of 1311 (~655) and yield a similar amount for Player 2 (roughly 656 in my perspective). (Note that even a “fair” split from my own perspective is above my disagreement value.) 

A division is determined by the offer I make: the list [n1, n2, n3, n4, n5] indicates exactly how many units of each item I will “give” to Player 2; I then get what remains. In other words, if I offer [a, b, c, d, e] then my allocation (by item) is:  

  item1: (5 – a)  
  item2: (5 – b)  
  item3: (5 – c)  
  item4: (5 – d)  
  item5: (7 – e)  

My resulting value is:  
  69×(5 – a) + 21×(5 – b) + 57×(5 – c) + 41×(5 – d) + 53×(7 – e).  

I would like my deal to yield about 655 in my utility. Since the full total is 1311, it is equivalent to offering Player 2 a “package” valued (by my own numbers) at 1311 – 655 = 656. In other words, I want to choose nonnegative integers a, b, c, d, e (within availability: a, b, c, d ∈ [0,5] and e ∈ [0,7]) satisfying: 

  69a + 21b + 57c + 41d + 53e = 656. 

One solution is to set:  
  a = 3, b = 0, c = 2, d = 3, e = 4. 

Let’s check:  
  69×3 = 207  
  21×0 = 0  
  57×2 = 114  
  41×3 = 123  
  53×4 = 212  
  Total = 207 + 0 + 114 + 123 + 212 = 656.  

Then my allocation is:  
  item 1: 5 – 3 = 2 units → 2×69 = 138  
  item 2: 5 – 0 = 5 units → 5×21 = 105  
  item 3: 5 – 2 = 3 units → 3×57 = 171  
  item 4: 5 – 3 = 2 units → 2×41 = 82  
  item 5: 7 – 4 = 3 units → 3×53 = 159  
  Sum = 138 + 105 + 171 + 82 + 159 = 655  

This gives me 655 (while in my perspective Player 2 would get a package valued at 656). This is appealing to me since it is well above my outside offer—and it is a fairly “balanced” division from my viewpoint. 

Thus, my action as Player 1 in round 1 is to make this counteroffer. 

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [3, 0, 2, 3, 4]}

Step 1: Note that if we ACCEPT Player 1’s current offer (which gives us [3, 0, 2, 3, 4]), our value would be
  3•22 + 0•31 + 2•100 + 3•47 + 4•70 = 66 + 0 + 200 + 141 + 280 = 687.
In round 1 the discount factor is 0.98^(0)=1, so we’d effectively obtain 687 in utility. However, our private outside offer is worth 1084. Accepting 687 for ourselves is much worse than our guaranteed fallback.

Step 2: As Player 2 we get to propose a counteroffer. In any counteroffer we propose, we indicate what we give to Player 1; our allocation will be whatever remains from the total available:
  • Item 1: total 5 – we propose to give y1 to Player 1, so we keep (5 – y1)
  • Item 2: total 5 – keep (5 – y2)
  • Item 3: total 5 – keep (5 – y3)
  • Item 4: total 5 – keep (5 – y4)
  • Item 5: total 7 – keep (7 – y5)
Our value for the deal is:
  22•(5–y1) + 31•(5–y2) + 100•(5–y3) + 47•(5–y4) + 70•(7–y5)
We want this (undiscounted in round 1) to be at least as large as our outside offer, 1084.

Step 3: We can “save” value by keeping the high‐value items (for us, item 3 is highest at 100/unit and item 5 is next at 70/unit) and by offering away some of the “cheaper” items (item 1 at 22/unit and item 2 at 31/unit). One viable division is to give away all of item 1 (5 units) and all of item 2 (5 units) and give away 3 units of item 4:
  • For item 1: giving away 5 units costs 5×22 = 110 (we keep 0 units)
  • For item 2: giving away 5 units costs 5×31 = 155 (we keep 0 units)
  • For item 4: giving away 3 units costs 3×47 = 141 (we keep 2 units)
The total “cost” (in terms of our value) is 110 + 155 + 141 = 406.
Since our total value for all items is 1490, what we keep has value 1490 – 406 = 1084 – exactly equal to our outside offer.
For the remaining items we give nothing away:
  • Item 3: give 0 (keep all 5 units)
  • Item 5: give 0 (keep all 7 units)

Thus, our proposed counteroffer is giving Player 1:
  Item 1: 5, Item 2: 5, Item 3: 0, Item 4: 3, Item 5: 0.
That means our allocation would be:
  Item 1: 0, Item 2: 0, Item 3: 5, Item 4: 2, Item 5: 7,
and our overall value would be exactly 1084.

Step 4: While this division leaves us just at our outside offer, it improves upon the current offer that gives us only 687 without risking a breakdown later in the negotiation.

Thus, our action in round 1 is to make this counteroffer.

My total value if I got everything would be 454. (For example, item‐1: 2×21, item‐2: 4×6, item‐3: 3×56, item‐4: 9×15, item‐5: 5×17 add up to 454.) In a one‐round (or early‐round) deal the discount factor is 1, so I must do at least about as well as my fallback.

Because I value most items very highly (my “pie” is only worth 454) I can afford to concede at most a very small amount – on the order of 16 points from 454. Looking at my unit values, even conceding one unit of my “cheapest” item (item 2, which is worth 6 for me) would cost me 6 points, and I could perhaps concede two units (12 points) to get even 2 units’ worth of share for Player 2. However, Player 2’s private values (drawn uniformly from 1 to 101) are likely to be around 51 per unit on average, so even 2 units give him an expected 102 worth in his own terms. That is far below what his outside offer is likely to be (since his total value if he got everything would be roughly 23×51 ≃ 1173, so his outside offer averages about 586).

Thus, any offer I could “improve” over my fallback (438) would require me to give Player 2 so much (because he has an excellent fallback too) that my own share would drop below 438. In round 1 the deal is not discounted yet, so waiting or going back and forth can only hurt me. I cannot craft any division of the items that gives me more than 438 and at the same time gives Player 2 at least his expected fallback value (roughly 586 or so, in his own terms). 

Under these circumstances the only “rational” move for me is to avoid any delay that would force me to ultimately get less than 438. (Any counteroffer that gives him any positive allocation would force me to sacrifice enough value – from my pie of 454 – so that I’d get less than my fallback.) 

So my best action in round 1 is simply to WALK away and secure my outside offer of 438 rather than risk a drawn‐out negotiation that would only force discounting or require me to concede too much.
